We distinguish rates at which carbon deposition occurs during initiation, rates at which catalytic centers are lost during deactivation, and paraffin-to-olefin ratio during propagation as benchmarks that distinguish 5 wt% Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA (Si/Al = 13.5) catalysts during dimethyl ether (DME) homologation in the presence of hydrogen. Studies that systematically vary initial DME contact time (210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1), DME pressure (4 and 22 kPa), and H2 pressure (1, 24, and 48 kPa) reveal that Cu enables lower carbon deposition rates (on a per proton basis) in the induction period, increases the effluent paraffin-to-olefin ratio during propagation, and decreases instantaneous site-loss yields during termination by 1.5–2× (moles of active sites lost per mole of DME) thus augmenting the degree of product saturation and catalyst stability during DME homologation. These results provide mechanistic insights revealing the critical role of Cu in facilitating DME homologation to high value, high-octane gasoline-range hydrocarbons with higher cumulative turnovers than proton form H-BEA. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords High-octane gasoline Methanol to hydrocarbons Deactivation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The conversion of methanol/dimethyl ether (DME) to hydrocarbons over solid acid catalysts presents a route for the synthesis of light olefins, aromatics, branched alkanes, and gasoline-range distillate via syngas as an intermediate chemical platform to enable valorization of any low-value carbon feedstock [1–3]. Among these hydrocarbons, branched hydrocarbons, especially, 2,2,3-trimethylbutane (triptane), is of particular interest because of its high research octane number (RON = 112.8) [4]. Reaction conditions typical of methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) at temperatures above 573 K often yield branched aliphatics with low selectivities while DME conversion on H-BEA at lower temperatures (450–500 K) yields triptane (~33 %) and isobutane (~35 %) with high carbon selectivity as shown by Iglesia and coworkers [5–8]. Simonetti et al. [9] reported kinetic and isotopic evidence for chain growth and termination pathways that selectively form triptane and isobutane from DME using competitive reactions between 13C-DME and unlabeled alkenes to assess rates of individual methylation, hydrogen transfer, isomerization, and β-scission reactions. These mechanistic studies showed that the high selectivity to branched C4 and C7 paraffins and olefins is controlled by the relative rates of methylation-to-hydrogen transfer, carbocation stability, and facile β-scission of C8+ chains [9]. Methanol (CH3OH = CH2 + H2O) and DME (CH3OCH3 = 2CH2+ H2O) can be considered to have -CH2- stoichiometry as water is formed as a stoichiometric byproduct in methanol/DME homologation. Alkane (CnH2n+2) formation in methanol/DME homologation, thus is always accompanied by hydrogen deficient products, including alkylated aromatics, e.g., hexamethylbenzene (HMB) and polycyclic hydrocarbons, that serve as coke precursors and contribute towards the rapid catalyst deactivation observed [5,9]. Research reports from NREL [10–12] have demonstrated that addition of copper to an H-BEA zeolite formulation (Cu/H-BEA) results in a two-fold increase in hydrocarbon productivity and over four-fold longer time-on-stream operation compared to unmodified H-BEA during DME homologation. These studies, however, do not explicate the mechanistic roles of Cu on the initiation, propagation, and termination sequences during DME homologation over H-BEA at conditions relevant for selective triptane synthesis. Methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) catalysis proceeds via a chain carrier mechanism with distinct phases of initiation, propagation, and termination [13]. During the initiation period, prior to the auto-catalytic propagation phase, unsaturated hydrocarbons are formed within the pores of the zeolite catalyst which subsequently act as chain carriers for C-C bond formation [14–23]. Following an induction period in which olefinic and aromatic components of the “hydrocarbon pool” accrue, these species undergo successive methylation/cracking events to promote C1 homologation during the autocatalytic propagation phase [24–27]. The organic components of active chain carriers are ultimately transformed into highly unsaturated carbonaceous residues, resulting in termination of chain carriers and deactivation [28–33]. We draw analogy between MTH and DME conversion over solid acid catalysts to identify and characterize these distinct phases in DME homologation in order to determine the mechanistic roles of Cu in triptane synthesis. We demonstrate, by systematically varying initial DME contact time, H2 pressure, and DME pressure, that copper enables lower carbon deposition rates (on a per proton basis) in the induction period while it enables higher effluent paraffin-to-olefin ratio (1.5–2×), higher degree of product saturation, and lower aromatic selectivity (~2×) during the propagation sequence. Further, comparison of instantaneous site-loss yields at these process conditions shows that copper mitigates deactivation by reducing the rate at which active sites are lost during DME homologation. These findings define benchmarks and targets in developing improved catalyst formulations for the conversion of methanol/DME to fuels. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials characterization Beta zeolite with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 27 (Si/Al = 13.5) and a particle size of 45 – 125 µm was obtained in ammonium form from Tosoh. The catalyst was treated in flowing dry air (1.67 cm3 s−1) to 823 K at a ramp rate of 2 K s−1 for 10 h to give the proton form material denoted as H-BEA. Supported Cu on BEA zeolite, denoted as Cu/H-BEA, was prepared using incipient wetness impregnation with the Cu loading determined using ICP-OES analysis (5 wt%) [10]. Structural and characteristics of H-BEA and 5 wt% Cu/H-BEA materials used in this study probed using powder X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy, have been reported previously [10]. 27Al NMR spectra for these samples before and after reaction were reported by Ruddy et al. [12] to show that no octahedral extraframework aluminum moieties exist in the H-BEA or Cu/H-BEA samples. The bulk crystal structure of 5 wt% Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA matched the reported structure for BEA [34] as confirmed by XRD patterns. Transmission electron microscopy confirmed the presence of polydispersed metallic Cu nanoparticles with diameters ranging from 2 to 60 nm [10]. The total number of acid sites were determined using NH3 TPD according to the procedure described in section S1. The values reported from NH3 TPD in this report are in quantitative agreement with values determined by isopropylamine titration (section S1). 2.2 Catalytic testing DME homologation reactions were carried out in a stainless steel packed-bed reactor (1/4 in OD; 0.035 in wall thickness) at 493 K and atmospheric pressure with pressures measured using a pressure transducer (Omega). The catalyst bed was supported between quartz wool plugs and heated using an ARI heating coil regulated by a Watlow Temperature Controller (96 Series). A K-type thermocouple (Omega Engineering 0.020 in probe diameter) was used for measuring the temperature of the catalyst bed during the reaction. Reactions were performed using ~200 mg catalyst that was pressed, crushed, and sieved between 40- and 80-mesh sieves to obtain uniformly sized particles. Prior to reaction, the catalysts were pretreated in dry air (1.67 cm3 s−1) to 823 K (at a ramp rate of 2 K s−1) for 10 h before cooling to the desired reaction temperature in helium (99.995 % purity, Matheson). Cu/H-BEA catalyst was subjected to an additional H2 (99.9 % purity, Airgas) treatment (1.67 cm3 s−1) at 573 K for 5 h before cooling to the reaction temperature. DME homologation was performed at 493 K by varying the initial DME contact time (210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1), DME pressure (4 kPa and 22 kPa, 99.8 % purity, Matheson), and hydrogen pressure (4 kPa, 24 kPa, and 48 kPa). A balance of argon was used to maintain total pressure in the system to be atmospheric. Gases were fed to the reactor via calibrated Brooks 5850 S/SLA5850 series mass flow controllers. The reactant stream was carried to and from the reactor via stainless steel lines heated to a temperature higher than 443 K. The effluent stream was monitored by an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector for analysis of permanent gases (Ar) and water, and a methyl siloxane capillary column (HP-1, 50 m x 320 µm x 0.52 µm) connected to a flame ionization detector for analysis of oxygenates and hydrocarbons. GC analysis with high temporal resolution was achieved using a sixteen-position selector (VICI Valco) that can step incrementally to store reactor effluent mixtures at timed intervals (300 s) for later analysis. (9), and (ii) instantaneous contact time, τ (molH+ s (mol C)−1), which changes with time-on-stream as active sites are continuously lost to catalyst deactivation and is calculated using Eq. (10). (9) τ initial = H + 0 n ˙ C , DME , in (10) τ = H + ( t ) n ˙ C , DME , in where, [H+] ( t ) represents the number of Brønsted acid sites at time t. We use instantaneous contact time τ to assess deactivation metrics in Section 3.3 as deactivation in this chemistry is caused only by a decrease in the number of H+ active sites during DME homologation over H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA (vide infra). The instantaneous contact time provides a precise measure of the number of catalytic sites available for reaction at any instant of time (or reaction progress) in deactivating catalyst beds and sensitively determines conversion and product selectivity trends during DME homologation. This metric is further agnostic as to which species cause deactivation so far as the end result is that sites which are available for reaction in deactivated beds catalyze rates with the same rate and selectivity as sites in a fresh catalyst bed. 2.4 Site-loss descriptors We use metrics specific to the rate at which sites in the catalyst bed are lost following a recent report by Foley et al. [35] to assess deactivation of Cu/H-BEA catalysts. In systems that exhibit non-selective deactivation, where the decrease in conversion with reaction progress is prescribed solely by a decrease in number of sites, the rate at which active sites in the bed are lost can be expressed as a product of two variables, dX/dτ and dτ/dt as shown in Eq. (12). It has been shown that the rate of decrease in conversion with time, dX/dt, conflates a decrease in the number of active sites available for catalysis with time-on-stream, represented by dτ/dt, and the reaction kinetics reflected by the quantity dX/dτ, the change in conversion as a function of contact time [36]. Here, deactivation is assessed through a numerical descriptor, site-loss yield, that is prescribed analytically when considering catalytic sites to be reactants in deactivation events where two of the three quantities, dX/dτ and dX/dt, are measured such that the third, dτ/dt, is assessed. (11)-(13) in our study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dimethyl ether homologation on H-BEA and 5 wt% Cu/H-BEA: identification of induction period, propagation, and termination regimes Fig. 1 shows the conversion and cumulative selectivity profiles as a function of catalyst turnovers during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts at 493 K in the presence of 45 kPa H2. DME conversion on Cu/H-BEA catalysts starts at 9.7 % and increases within the first 5 catalyst turnovers to a maximum conversion of 33.2 % (Fig. 1a). DME conversion on H-BEA starts at 4.8 % and increases with reaction progress within the first 3 catalyst turnovers to a maximum conversion of 16.8 % (Fig. 1b). The observed increase in DME conversion with reaction progress at early catalyst turnovers is analogous to the initial increase in methanol conversion during MTH at early catalyst turnovers, characteristic of an induction period in which organic species associated with the hydrocarbon pool accumulate [37–39]. The increase in DME conversion coincides with changes in the selectivities of C4 and C7 paraffins as noted by Ahn et al. [5] and shown in Fig. 1a and b. Rapid on-stream deactivation is observed thereafter as reflected in the decrease in DME conversion with time-on-stream (Fig. 1), where the catalyst lifetime, assessed by total turnovers (Eq. 4, after the conversion drops below 10 %), is lower on H-BEA than that on Cu/H-BEA by a factor of ~2. The difference in total catalyst turnovers on H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA is further accompanied by differences in product selectivity trends where the cumulative selectivity to aromatics is higher and paraffins selectivity (e.g., isobutane) is lower on H-BEA relative to Cu/H-BEA (Fig. 1). We inquire the mechanistic roles of Cu in impacting product selectivity and conversion profiles during DME homologation by first identifying distinct regimes associated with the induction, propagation, and termination periods during DME homologation and subsequently noting how product selectivity trends in each regime are altered by the addition of Cu to H-BEA formulations. Figs. 2 and 3 show the instantaneous selectivities of C4-C7 hydrocarbons as a function of conversion during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts respectively at 493 K acquired at three distinct initial contact times, 210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1. We note that the product selectivity versus conversion data for DME homologation overlay irrespective of the initial contact time, (data shown by filled circles in Figs. 2 and 3) except for the data acquired during the first few turnovers (data shown by open circles in Figs. 2 and 3). We attribute the differences in selectivity versus conversion profiles among H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA to differences in the reaction pathways that induce changes in conversion with reaction progress. For experiments performed at initial contact time of 210 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1, conversion initially increases from 9.7 % (open black circles, Fig. 2) to 33.8 % (filled black circles, Fig. 2) on Cu/H-BEA and 5 % (open black circles, Figs. 3) to 16.7 % (filled black circles, Fig. 3) on H-BEA due to the formation of unsaturated hydrocarbons within the channels of H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA while conversion decreases at later catalyst turnovers as active sites are lost to prescribe catalyst deactivation. The distinction in product selectivity at early and late catalyst turnovers allows us to associate the early catalyst turnovers, 5 and 3 turnovers for Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA respectively, with the induction period during DME homologation and associate the maximum conversion to the onset of propagation and termination sequences where olefins and aromatics undergo successive methylation/cracking events to promote C1 homologation while active sites are lost concurrently and continuously to catalyst deactivation. Further, for experiments performed at an initial contact time of 94 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1 conversion increases from 17 % (open red circles, Figs. 2) to 21.1 % (filled red circles, Fig. 2) on Cu/H-BEA during the initial 7 turnovers and from 4.8 % (open red circles, Figs. 3) to 9.7 % (filled red circles, Fig. 3) on H-BEA during the initial 5 turnovers affirming a catalyst induction period at early turnovers. The conversion decreases at later turnovers, and we associate the maximum conversion to the onset of propagation and termination sequences because correspondent with the maximum conversion we also observe selectivity-conversion profiles to overlay for all samples and process conditions examined. Similar trends in conversion are observed on Cu/H-BEA (8 % (open green circles, Fig. 2) to 12 % (filled green circles, Fig. 2)) and H-BEA catalysts (2.7 % (open green circles, Figs. 3) to 5.4 %, (filled green circles, Fig. 3)) during the initial 5 turnovers at an initial contact time of 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1 confirming the presence of an initial induction period. The congruence of conversion-selectivity profiles for C4-C7 hydrocarbons during the propagation and termination sequences of DME homologation (between 4.8-33.8 % for Cu/H-BEA and between 2.5-16.8 % for H-BEA, shown by solid circles in Fig. 2 and 3) at the three distinct initial contact times demonstrates that the deactivation of H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA is non-selective where changes in conversion and selectivity are entirely prescribed by a decrease in contact time. This characteristic of overlap in selectivity versus conversion profile is observed on H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA catalysts at 473 K as well (Fig. S3 and S4). We elaborate on the non-selective nature of deactivation and characterize the propagation and termination sequences of DME homologation in detail in Section 3.3. We note that despite the selectivity versus conversion data overlaying for fresh and partially deactivated catalyst beds for both H-BEA (Fig. 3) and Cu/H-BEA (Fig. 2), product selectivity and conversion trends during DME homologation are distinct among H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA. We discuss these distinctions in detail in Section 3.2 and identify the role of Cu during DME homologation by calculating the carbon deposition, paraffin-to-olefin ratio, hydrogen-to-carbon ratio, and instantaneous site-loss yield using metrics defined in Sections 2.2 and 2.4 to characterize the induction period, propagation, and termination regimes individually. 3.2 Induction period characteristics As shown in Figs. 2 and 3, selectivity to C4-C7 hydrocarbons increases with increasing DME conversion during the induction period (open circles) and is distinct during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts. We attribute the differences in product selectivity trends during the induction period to the effects of Cu on carbon deposition characteristics, quantified using carbon-loss selectivity and cumulative carbon deposition defined in Section 2.2. As shown in Fig. 4, carbon loss selectivity during the induction period for Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts at 210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1 initial contact times are 1.5–2× lower on Cu/H-BEA than H-BEA when compared at similar catalyst turnovers, suggesting that fewer moles of unsaturated carbonaceous residues are deposited on Cu/H-BEA catalysts than H-BEA for every mole of DME consumed. Further, the cumulative moles of carbon deposited per Brønsted acid site are lower in the case of Cu/H-BEA catalysts at the three initial contact times (210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1) as shown in Fig. 5. These trends are in line with that reported by Wu et al. [11] who carried out comparative studies on post reaction Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts (collected from the reactor after 22 h time-on-stream) using in situ spectroscopy to investigate the effects of Cu addition on surface carbon deposition. Their results showed that Cu suppresses the formation of polycyclic aromatics evidenced by the absence of a shoulder at 420 nm in diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible (DR-UV–vis) absorbance spectra of post reaction Cu/H-BEA catalysts under He [11]. These results suggest that Cu enables lower carbon deposition on a per proton basis during the induction period to mitigate catalyst deactivation thus reaching maximum conversion at higher turnover numbers than H-BEA (Fig. 1) due to slower buildup of organic species, improving the catalyst lifetime on Cu/H-BEA. 3.3 Propagation and termination period characteristics As described in Section 3.1, we define the onset of propagation and termination sequences when the instantaneous selectivities begin to overlay with conversion at the three initial contact times. We investigate the functional role of Cu by characterizing the propagation sequences with paraffin-to-olefin ratio as a function of reaction progress associated with cumulative turnovers. As shown in Figs. 6–8, the Cu/H-BEA sample accomplishes more catalyst turnovers (2–3.1×, Fig. 6), achieves higher paraffin-to-olefin ratio (Figs. 6, 1.2–1.4×), higher hydrogen-to-carbon ratios (Fig. 7), and lower aromatics selectivity (Fig. 8, ~3×), than H-BEA when compared at similar catalyst turnovers at all three initial DME contact times (210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1). The formation of paraffins during DME homologation via bimolecular hydrogen transfer reactions requires an equivalent amount of H2 to be supplied, which results in the formation of hydrogen deficient species, such as dienes and aromatics, in stoichiometric proportion. The lower aromatics selectivity and higher paraffin-to-olefin ratio observed during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA relative to H-BEA contradicts this expectation, suggesting that there must present other pathways contributing to paraffins formation (Fig. 6) and increments in H/C ratios (Fig. 7) during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA in the presence of H2 co-feeds. Schaidle et al. [10] also observed an increase in paraffin-to-olefin ratio and attributed the observed increase in paraffins formation to olefin hydrogenation by metallic Cu nanoparticles instead of bimolecular hydrogen transfer events on H+ sites. The activation and incorporation of H2 was further explored in isotopic labeling experiments by cofeeding D2 with DME over H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA to note deuterium incorporation in all hydrocarbon products in Cu/H-BEA confirming C-D bond formation. Consequently, we surmise that Cu increases the effluent paraffin-to-olefin ratio and the degree of product saturation while lowering aromatics selectivity by facilitating olefins hydrogenation and direct incorporation of H2 from gas streams. The addition of Cu not only affects product selectivity during propagation and termination sequences during MTH but affects catalyst lifetime (Fig. 1), as assessed by the cumulative catalyst turnovers, and the rate of catalyst deactivation. Figs. 2 and 3 demonstrate that the product selectivity versus conversion data of partially deactivated catalyst beds overlays with that of fresh catalyst beds (solid circles), evidencing that deactivation during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA is non-selective where any changes in DME conversion with reaction progress are a result of changes in the instantaneous contact time, τ (Section 2.3) and hence, the number of active sites available for catalysis at any instant in time. The non-selective nature of catalyst deactivation allows quantitative description of the rate of catalyst deactivation during DME homologation using site-loss yield, as reported by Foley et al. [35]. The calculation of site-loss yield, dτ/dt, however, requires the measurement of both steady-state conversion versus contact time curves ( Fig. 9) and conversion versus time curves during DME homologation for calculation of dX/dτ and dX/dt, respectively, as detailed in Eq. 13 (Section 2.4). We obtain dX/dτ by plotting the maximum conversion, the conversion at which instantaneous selectivities begin to overlay after the initiation of hydrocarbon pool but before any significant catalyst deactivation occurs (Fig. 1), against initial contact time τinital during DME homologation reactions on Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA catalysts at 493 K. The data were fitted by two continuous and differentiable polynomial functions that allow for the calculation of the instantaneous values of contact time from the inverse of the polynomial function in Fig. 8 for any given conversion. Derivatives of these polynomials allow for the calculation of dX/dτ while derivatives of the conversion vs. time-on-stream profiles allow calculation of dX/dt (Fig. S7), which, when taken together, enable the calculation of instantaneous site-loss yield (Eq. 13) for quantitative evaluation of catalyst deactivation during DME homologation on H-BEA and Cu/H-BEA ( Fig. 10). Fig. 10 shows that the instantaneous site-loss yields are lower during DME homologation on Cu/H-BEA than those on H-BEA by a factor of ~1.5–2× for the three initial contact times studied. This indicates that for every mole of DME fed, fewer number of active sites are lost on Cu/H-BEA catalyst than on H-BEA. Lower site-loss yield is observed on Cu/H-BEA than on H-BEA during DME homologation at varying partial pressures of H2 (1, 24, and 48 kPa) and DME (4 and 22 kPa) and this observation is consistent with lower cumulative carbon deposition (Fig. 4) and carbon loss-selectivity (Fig. 5) observed in the induction period during DME conversion on Cu/H-BEA. Thus, the addition of Cu mitigates catalyst deactivation by decreasing the rate at which active sites are lost during termination sequences and the rate at which carbon is deposited during the induction period which, when taken together, rationalizes the operability to longer times-on-stream of Cu/H-BEA during DME homologation. Considering the results above, the Cu/H-BEA catalyst achieves a two-fold increase in catalyst lifetime during DME homologation (assessed by total turnovers) at 493 K in comparison to H-BEA and shifts selectivity towards gasoline-range hydrocarbons with higher octane rating. The underlying chemistry can be conceived in context of “hydrocarbon pool” mechanism for MTH. The addition of Cu offers benefit in the degree of product saturation and catalyst stability which at a mechanistic level is described by lower carbon deposition rates in the induction period, higher paraffin-to-olefin ratio during propagation, and lower instantaneous site-loss yields during the termination sequence. 4 Conclusions Addition of Cu (5 wt%) to H-BEA during DME homologation in presence of hydrogen enables lower carbon deposition rates (on a per proton basis) in the induction period and increases the effluent paraffin-to-olefin ratio (1.5–2×) and degree of product saturation in comparison to H-BEA catalysts, by lowering aromatics selectivity during propagation. Further, comparison of instantaneous site-loss yields shows that copper mitigates deactivation by mitigating the active site loss during DME homologation. These results demonstrate the functional role Cu in improving catalyst lifetime and proffer metrics and targets for optimizing zeolite based catalysts useful for the conversion of methanol/DME to fuels. coredata.dc:description: We distinguish rates at which carbon deposition occurs during initiation, rates at which catalytic centers are lost during deactivation, and paraffin-to-olefin ratio during propagation as benchmarks that distinguish 5 wt% Cu/H-BEA and H-BEA (Si/Al = 13.5) catalysts during dimethyl ether (DME) homologation in the presence of hydrogen. Studies that systematically vary initial DME contact time (210, 94, and 45 molH+, initial s (mol C)−1), DME pressure (4 and 22 kPa), and H2 pressure (1, 24, and 48 kPa) reveal that Cu enables lower carbon deposition rates (on a per proton basis) in the induction period, increases the effluent paraffin-to-olefin ratio during propagation, and decreases instantaneous site-loss yields during termination by 1.5–2× (moles of active sites lost per mole of DME) thus augmenting the degree of product saturation and catalyst stability during DME homologation. These results provide mechanistic insights revealing the critical role of Cu in facilitating DME homologation to high value, high-octane gasoline-range hydrocarbons with higher cumulative turnovers than proton form H-BEA.
coredata.dc:title: Benchmarking Cu/BEA and HBEA catalysts for high-octane gasoline synthesis
